Since we model the dice as a rigid body, we will lose this effect.
We do not model for ground deformation or air drag.

. The four paths separate the phase space into four sections.
Within each section, two arbitrarily close initial conditions always lead to arbitrarily close paths. Only when two initial conditions are in
sections, separated just by the border, can the anomaly appear.

So, it is practically highly difficult.
This is a common obstacle for many of our inquiries in this project: high dimensional data are hard to compute, and even harder to visualize.
The cause of this repetition is unknown.

What it Means to Be in the Same Cell
Please find the animation at 0:30 of the demo video:
Judging from the dice rolling animation, the three yellow throws look similar. Among the three blue throws,
the bottom one goes to “1” via “4”, while the other two go to “1” via “5”.
It would be interesting to see if the two
sections are fundamentally a same 6D cell.
